verses.verse: Soon after in Iconium, they both went together into the Jew's synagogue and spake the same thing, so that a large group of both Jews and Greeks believed.
But the unbelieving Jews incited the Gentiles and made their minds to be very angry against the brethren.
So for a long time they stayed there speaking boldly about the Lord, who evidenced the word of his grace and allowed signs and wonders to be done by their hands.
But the multitude of the city was divided, some where with the Jews and some with the Apostles.
So when both the Gentiles and Jews together with their leaders lashed out to abuse and to stone them,
and they realized it, they fled to Lystra and Derbe, cities in Lycaonia, and areas around them
and preached the gospel there.
At Lystra there was a certain man, crippled from his mother's womb, who had no strength in his feet and who had never walked.
He heard Paul speak, and he was watching him closely and perceiving that he had faith to be healed.
[Paul] said with a loud voice, "Stand up on your feet." So he jumped up and walked.
After the people saw what Paul had done, they shouted with their voices saying in the Lycaonia language, "The gods have come down to us in the likeness of men."
They called Barnabas, Zeus, and Paul, Hermes, because he was the spokesman.
Then the priest of Zeus (whose [temple] was in front of the city) brought oxen and religious wreathes to the gates and would have sacrificed along with the people.
When the apostles Barnabas and Paul heard this, they tore their clothes and ran among the people, shouting,

"Sirs, why are you doing these things? We also are men with the same human nature as you. We preach to you that you should turn from these empty idols and [turn] to the living God who made heaven, earth, sea, and everything in them. Act 14:16 In former times he left all nations alone to live in their own ways.
"Nevertheless, he did not leave himself without witness, in that he did good and gave us rain from heaven and bountiful harvests filling our hearts with food and joy."
Even after saying these things, they scarcely were able to restrain the people, so that they wouldn't sacrifice to them.
Then some Jews from Antioch and Iconium came and persuaded the crowd, and after stoning Paul, dragged him out of the city thinking that he was dead.
However, as the disciples stood around him, he got up and came into the city, and left the next day with Barnabas to [go to] Derbe.
After preaching the gospel to that city and having taught many, they returned to Lystra, Iconium, and Antioch
strengthening the souls of the disciples and encouraging them to continue in the faith and that we must through much hardships enter the Kingdom of God.
After they had chosen elders in every church and after praying with fasting, they committed them to the Lord on whom they had believed.
After passing through Pisidia, they came to Pamphylia.

When they had preached in the Word in Perga, they went down to Attalia, Act 14:26 and from there sailed to Antioch from where they had been entrusted to the grace of God for the work, which they fulfilled.
After they had come and the church was gathered together, they reported everything that God had done through them, and how he had opened the door of faith for the Gentiles.
Then they stayed there a long time with the disciples.
